segment.source: This article explains how to support copy and paste in Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps using the clipboard.
segment.target: This article explains how to support copy and paste in Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps using the clipboard.

segment.source: Copy and paste
segment.target: Copy and paste

segment.source: Copy and paste
segment.target: Copy and paste

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: This article explains how to support copy and paste in Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps using the clipboard.
segment.target: This article explains how to support copy and paste in Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps using the clipboard.

segment.source: Copy and paste is the classic way to exchange data either between apps, or within an app, and almost every app can support clipboard operations to some degree.
segment.target: Copy and paste is the classic way to exchange data either between apps, or within an app, and almost every app can support clipboard operations to some degree.

segment.source: Check for built-in clipboard support
segment.target: Check for built-in clipboard support

segment.source: In many cases, you do not need to write code to support clipboard operations.
segment.target: In many cases, you do not need to write code to support clipboard operations.

segment.source: Many of the default XAML controls you can use to create apps already support clipboard operations.
segment.target: Many of the default XAML controls you can use to create apps already support clipboard operations.

segment.source: For more information about which controls are available, see the controls listControlsList.
segment.target: For more information about which controls are available, see the controls listControlsList.

segment.source: Get set up
segment.target: Get set up

segment.source: First, include the Windows.ApplicationModel.DataTransferDataTransfer namespace in your app.
segment.target: First, include the Windows.ApplicationModel.DataTransferDataTransfer namespace in your app.

segment.source: Then, add an instance of the DataPackageDataPackage object.
segment.target: Then, add an instance of the DataPackageDataPackage object.

segment.source: This object contains both the data the user wants to copy and any properties (such as a description) that you want to include.
segment.target: This object contains both the data the user wants to copy and any properties (such as a description) that you want to include.

segment.source: Copy and cut
segment.target: Copy and cut

segment.source: Copy and cut (also referred to as move) work almost exactly the same.
segment.target: Copy and cut (also referred to as move) work almost exactly the same.

segment.source: Choose which operation you want using the DataPackage.RequestedOperationRequestedOperation property.
segment.target: Choose which operation you want using the DataPackage.RequestedOperationRequestedOperation property.

segment.source: Next, you can add the data that a user has selected to the DataPackageDataPackage object.
segment.target: Next, you can add the data that a user has selected to the DataPackageDataPackage object.

segment.source: If this data is supported by the DataPackage class, you can use one of the corresponding methods in the DataPackage object.
segment.target: If this data is supported by the DataPackage class, you can use one of the corresponding methods in the DataPackage object.

segment.source: Here's how to add text:
segment.target: Here's how to add text:

segment.source: The last step is to add the DataPackageDataPackage to the clipboard by calling the static Clipboard.SetContentSetContent method.
segment.target: The last step is to add the DataPackageDataPackage to the clipboard by calling the static Clipboard.SetContentSetContent method.

segment.source: Paste
segment.target: Paste

segment.source: To get the contents of the clipboard, call the static [Clipboard.GetContentGetContent method.
segment.target: To get the contents of the clipboard, call the static [Clipboard.GetContentGetContent method.

segment.source: This method returns a DataPackageViewDataPackageView that contains the content.
segment.target: This method returns a DataPackageViewDataPackageView that contains the content.

segment.source: This object is almost identical to a DataPackageDataPackage object, except that its contents are read-only.
segment.target: This object is almost identical to a DataPackageDataPackage object, except that its contents are read-only.

segment.source: With that object, you can use either the AvailableFormatsAvailableFormats or the ContainsContains method to identify what formats are available.
segment.target: With that object, you can use either the AvailableFormatsAvailableFormats or the ContainsContains method to identify what formats are available.

segment.source: Then, you can call the corresponding DataPackageView method to get the data.
segment.target: Then, you can call the corresponding DataPackageView method to get the data.

segment.source: Track changes to the clipboard
segment.target: Track changes to the clipboard

segment.source: In addition to copy and paste commands, you may also want to track clipboard changes.
segment.target: In addition to copy and paste commands, you may also want to track clipboard changes.

segment.source: Do this by handling the clipboard's Clipboard.ContentChangedContentChanged event.
segment.target: Do this by handling the clipboard's Clipboard.ContentChangedContentChanged event.
